title: The Biggest Playoff Risers in the NBAs Modern Era
text:
The NBA playoffs are approaching. Ring culture in the NBA has changed the way fans and players look at the game. “72-10 don’t mean a thing without the ring” is the famous Bulls slogan players wore after they set the record for regular-season wins in 1996. Close your eyes and picture the NBA Finals. If you are younger, you may think of Kyrie’s shot over Steph Curry, Kevin Garnett screaming ANYTHING IS POSSIBLE, or Kobe finally winning a ring without Shaq. What makes a good team great? What players add to winning at the highest level?
BPM, developed by Daniel Myers, aims to score how impactful a player is to the team’s success. Basketball Reference states that a 6th-man-level player has an average BPM of 0, and a good starter is 2.0. Usage percentage equates to how many possessions in a game end due to the player. A field goal attempt, turnover, and free throw attempt all affect the usage rate.
When the lights get brighter, players who increase their output and performance impact the team’s winning the most. The NBA’s leader for BPM in the playoffs is Michael Jordan, followed by Nikola Jokić and LeBron James. These players have above an 8 BPM, showcasing their career-long greatness.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

modernera <-read_csv("nba_player_advanced_2001_2024 (1).csv") |> filter(Season >2002) 
postmodern <-read_csv("nba_player_advanced_postseason_2001_2024 (1).csv") |> filter(Season >2002) 

reg01<- modernera |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  summarize(
    regsumbpm = mean(BPM),
    totalminutes = sum(MP),
    usage = mean(`USG%`)
  ) |> 
  filter( totalminutes > 1500)|>
  arrange(desc(regsumbpm))


post01<- postmodern |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  summarize(
    postsumbpm = mean(BPM),
    totalminutes = sum(MP),
    usage = mean(`USG%`)
  ) |> 
  filter( totalminutes > 1500) |>
  arrange(desc(postsumbpm))

FinalMerged <- reg01 |>  inner_join(post01, by = "Player")

bpmdiff <- FinalMerged |> 
  mutate(
    differential = postsumbpm - regsumbpm,
  ) |> 
arrange(desc(differential))

usagediff <- FinalMerged |> 
  mutate(
    differential = usage.y - usage.x,
  ) |> 
arrange(desc(differential))

bpmusage <- FinalMerged |> 
  mutate(
    differential = postsumbpm - regsumbpm,
    usagediff = usage.y - usage.x
  ) |> 
  filter(usage.x > 15) |> 
  filter(usagediff > -1) |>
  filter(totalminutes.y > 2000) |> 
  arrange(desc(differential))

topten <- bpmusage |> 
  filter(usage.x > 15) |> 
  filter(usagediff > -1) |>
  filter(differential > 0) |> 
  filter(totalminutes.y > 2000) |> 
top_n(10,differential) 


champions <- topten |> 
  filter(Player%in%c("LeBron James", "Rajon Rondo", "Boris Diaw","Draymond Green", "Danny Green", "Jamal Murray","Derrick White","Kobe Bryant"))

worst<- bpmusage |> 
  filter(Player%in%c("Udonis Haslem", "CJ McCollum", "Bam Adebayo"))

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=bpmusage, aes(x=differential, y=usagediff),color="darkgrey") +
  geom_point(data=topten, aes(x=differential, y=usagediff),colour = "red") +
  geom_point(data=champions, aes(x=differential, y=usagediff),colour = "gold") +
geom_point(data=worst, aes(x=differential, y=usagediff),colour = "#964B00")+
  geom_text_repel(
    data=topten, 
    aes(x=differential, y=usagediff, label=Player)) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=worst, 
    aes(x=differential, y=usagediff, label=Player)) +
  geom_text(aes(x=1.5, y=4, label="Higher Usage, Better Production"), color="blue") +
  geom_text(aes(x=-2, y=2, label="Higher Usage, Worse Production"), color="blue") +
    geom_vline(xintercept = 0,color="lightgrey") + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0,color="lightgrey") +
  labs(
    x=" Impact on the Game",
    y="Usage Difference from Playoffs to Regular Season", 
    title="What Players Increase Their Output in the Playoffs?", 
    subtitle="The players who have seen the biggest production increase from the regular season to the post season\nhave resulted in deep playoff runs. ", 
    caption="Source: Basketball Reference | Nolan Rachiele"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 19, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
     plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position = "none",
    ) 









The 10 best players whose BPM differential from the regular season to the playoffs is the highest include Josh Smith, Rajon Rondo, Derrick White, Danny Green, and Draymond Green. All of them have a differential greater than 2.0, meaning their postseason output is equivalent to a starter-level player better than their regular-season performance. Eight out of the ten most impactful playoff players have won rings.
Some of these players were their team’s first option. LeBron James and Kobe Bryant each had a playoff usage rate above 25 percent for their entire careers. However, most served as the second, third, or even fourth option behind bigger offensive stars.


Code
offense <- read_csv("NETRATINGONOFFPOSTOFFENSE.csv")
defense<- read_csv("NETRATINGONOFF.csv")

newd<- defense |> 
  rename(
    Player = 1,
    MinutesOn = 2,
    MinutesOff = 3,
    PTSon = 4,
    PTSoff = 5,
    DefNTR = 6
  )

o<- offense |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
summarise(
  Min = sum(`Minutes On`),
  MinOff = sum(`Minutes Off`),
  ONet = mean(`Offensive Net Rating`)
)


d <- newd |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
summarise(
  DMin = sum(MinutesOn),
  DMinOff = sum(MinutesOff),
  DefNet = mean(DefNTR))

joinedrating <- o |>  inner_join(d)

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=joinedrating, 
    aes(y=reorder(Player, ONet), x=ONet, xend=DefNet),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "#006400",
    colour_xend = "#FF4D00")+
   geom_vline(xintercept = 0,color="#4169e1")+
  labs(
    x="Net Rating Differential",
    y="", 
    title="Winning Means Impacting Both Sides of the Court", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:#006400;'>offensive net rating</span> is to the right of the <span style = 'color:#4169e1;'>line</span> the player adds points to their teams offense. If <span style = 'color:#FF4D00;'>defensive net rating</span> is to the left they take away points from the opposing team. The larger the gap, the more impactful the player is.",
    caption="Source: PBP Stats | Nolan Rachiele"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
      plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position = "none",
    )









A player’s net rating is calculated by subtracting the opposing team’s points per 100 possessions from the player’s offensive points per 100 possessions. A team’s net rating uses the same formula but is based on team performance while the player is off the court.
Among the 28 players who show an increase in both postseason usage and postseason BPM, 16 have won championships—highlighting the link between elevated playoff performance and team success.
Jamal Murray has the highest offensive net rating differential compared to his team. During Denver’s recent playoff run, the Nuggets scored 13 more points per 100 possessions with him on the court versus when he sat. However, they also allowed 3.8 more points on defense during those minutes.
The highest overall net rating differential belongs to Draymond Green. With him on the court, his team is +7.4 offensively and allows 5 fewer points per 100 possessions defensively—a testament to his two-way impact.


Code
allreg_seasons<- read_csv("allreg_seasons.csv")
allpost_seasons <-read_csv("allpost_seasons.csv")

postseason<- allpost_seasons |> 
   group_by(Player) |> 
  select(Player, MIN, Diff, `Exp W`) |> 
mutate(postseasondiff = Diff)


regseason <- allreg_seasons |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  select(Player, MIN, Diff, `Exp W`) |> 
mutate(regseasondiff = Diff)

groupedreg <- regseason |> 
  group_by(Player ) |> 
  summarise(
    minutes = sum(MIN),
    Expected = mean(`Exp W`),
    careerdifferential = mean(Diff), )

newpost <- postseason |> 
  rename(
   PostMin = MIN,
   PostDiff = Diff,
   PostExpW = `Exp W`)
   
groupedpost <- newpost |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  summarise(
    Postseasonminutes= sum(PostMin),
    Expectedwin = mean(PostExpW),
    postseasondiff = mean(postseasondiff)) 
cleaningglass <- groupedpost|> inner_join(groupedreg, by = "Player")

winsadded <- cleaningglass |> 
  mutate(
    wintotal = Expectedwin - Expected,
    addedpoints = postseasondiff - careerdifferential)

 top10 <- filter(winsadded, Player %in% c("Rajon Rondo","Danny Green","Draymond Green","Jamal Murray","Boris Diaw","Kobe Bryant","Lebron James","Dirk Nowitzki","Nikola Jokic","Khris Middleton","Dwayne Wade","Anthony Davis","Serge Ibaka","Jayson Tatum","Stephen Curry","Lamar Odom","Andre Iguodala","Giannis Antetokounmpo"))
champ <- top10 |> filter(Player %in% c("Draymond Green","Stephen Curry","Kobe Bryant","Danny Green","Dirk Nowitzki","Lamar Odom","Andre Iguodala"))

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=top10, aes(x=reorder(Player, Expectedwin), weight=Expectedwin),fill="lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=champ, aes(x=reorder(Player, Expectedwin), weight=Expectedwin), fill="#AA8833") +
  coord_flip()+
  geom_hline(yintercept = 1.001567398,color="#E11218",size=1.4) +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Expected Wins Added", 
    title="How do players net rating affect their playoff wins?", 
    subtitle="The career wins added for each champion players playoff career. The <span style = 'color:#E11218;'>average wins added</span> for an NBA career is 1.0015.The players highlighted in gold are multiple time champions",
    caption="Source: Cleaning Glass | Nolan Rachiele"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 7), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot" 
    )









Cleaning the glass aggregates player’s expected wins added to their teams postseason based on point differential. Draymond Green takes his second award of the day with the most career wins added to their team. That begs the question: is Draymond Green the greatest playoff riser of all time?

title: Does Steve Nash Deserve His 2005 MVP
text:
Steve Nash is often discredited and disrespected by his NBA peers and fans of the league. Fans overlooked Nash until he was 30 and joined the Phoenix Suns, where he propelled the team with the most explosive offensive output in the league and potentially altered league history. Did Steve Nash deserve his MVP’s or did other players deserve the award?
Nash’s 2004-05 Suns started the three-point explosion by showcasing the correlation between 3 point attempts and offensive rating. Ultimately, the more shots the Suns took ended in a higher pace and a higher offensive rating.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggrepel)
library(gt)
library(hoopR)


threes<-read_csv("Steve Nash Data/3ptandRTG.csv")
rap <-read_csv("Steve Nash Data/Raptor/Historical RAPTOR by Player.csv")
modern <-read_csv("advanced.csv")


raptor <- rap |> 
  filter(mp>1500)

rank <- raptor |>  
  filter(season %in% 2000:2024) |> 
  group_by(season) |> 
  arrange(desc(raptor_offense)) |> 
  mutate(raptor_rank = row_number())|> ungroup()  

three04<-threes |> 
group_by(Name,Season) |> 
summarize(
  Threes = sum(FG3A),
  rating = sum(OffRTG)
) |> 
  mutate(TeamSeason = paste(Name, Season))

all <- three04 |> 
  filter(
  (Name=="PHX" & Season %in% c("2004-05", "2005-06"))  |
  (Name=="MIA"& Season=="2004-05") |
  (Name=="LAL" & Season =="2005-06")
  )
phx <-three04 |> 
  filter(Name=="PHX")
mia <- three04 |> 
  filter(Name=="MIA"& Season=="2004-05")
lal <- three04 |> 
  filter(Name=="LAL" & Season =="2005-06")


ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=three04, aes(x=Threes, y=rating),color="lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=phx, aes(x=Threes, y=rating),colour = "#E56020") +
  geom_point(data=lal, aes(x=Threes, y=rating),colour = "#FDB927") +
  geom_point(data=mia, aes(x=Threes, y=rating),colour = "#98002E") +
   geom_text_repel(
    data=all, 
    aes(x=Threes, y=rating, label=TeamSeason))+ 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 1301.017,color="lightgrey") + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 106.9432,color="lightgrey") +
  labs(
    x= "Total Threes in a Season",
    y="Offensive Rating", 
    title="The Suns Pioneered the Most Efficient Offense in the NBA ", 
    subtitle="Mike D'Antoni created the 7-seconds or less offense and it changed the way we view basketball.", 
    caption="Source: PBP Stats | Nolan Rachiele"
    )  +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The Suns climbed to the top record in the league after going 29-53 the previous year. The only difference: Steve Nash and Quinten Richardson. The Suns went 2-6 when Nash did not suit up throughout the year.


Code
boxscore <- load_nba_team_box(
  seasons = 2005,
  season_type = 2,
  dbConnection = NULL,
  tablename = NULL
)

box <- boxscore |> 
  filter(season_type==2)

seasonwins <- box |> 
  group_by(team_name) |> 
  arrange(game_date) |> 
  mutate(
    win = case_when(
      team_winner == TRUE ~ 1,
      team_winner == FALSE ~ 0
    )
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    cumwins = cumsum(win)
  ) |> 
  ungroup()

phoenix <-seasonwins |> 
  filter(team_name == "Suns")
mavs <-seasonwins |> 
  filter(team_name == "Mavericks")
miami <-seasonwins |> 
  filter(team_name == "Heat")

ggplot() + 
  geom_step(data=seasonwins, aes(x=game_date, y=cumwins, group=team_name),color="lightgrey")+
geom_step(data=phoenix, aes(x=game_date, y=cumwins, group=team_name),color="#E56020")+
geom_step(data=mavs, aes(x=game_date, y=cumwins, group=team_name),color="#00538C") +
  geom_step(data=miami, aes(x=game_date, y=cumwins, group=team_name),color="#98002E")+ 
  annotate("rect", xmin = as.Date("2005-01-12"), xmax=as.Date("2005-01-22"), ymin = 0, ymax=Inf, fill="lightgrey", alpha=.5) + 
  geom_text(aes(x=as.Date("2005-01-17"), y=43, label="Steve Nash's\nFirst Injury"), color="black",size = 3) +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Wins", 
    title="Phoenix Suns Climbed to the Best Team in the League", 
    subtitle="The Suns had the best record over the course of the 2004 NBA season.They started the year 31-4\non the back of their newly acquired point guard. ", 
    caption="HoopR | Nolan Rachiele"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Estimated Plus/Minus tries to aggregate a player’s impact on their team. Steve Nash added the most points per 100 possessions on the offensive end. Sorting by MVP finish in the 2005 season, Steve Nash made the biggest impact on a team’s offensive production by adding close to 5 points per 100 possessions, the highest in the league. He was responsible for all of his team’s looks, averaging 12.9 open shots created by his production, which led the league in 05.


Code
epm <- read_csv("Steve Nash Data/EPM.csv")
epm04<- epm |> filter(Season==2005)
epm05<- epm |> filter(Season==2006)
nash04 <-epm |> filter((Player=="Steve Nash"& Season ==2005) |
  (Player == "Amar'e Stoudemire" & Season == 2005))
nash05 <-epm |> filter(Player=="Steve Nash"& Season ==2006) 
shaq <-epm |> filter(Player=="Shaquille O'Neal"& Season ==2005)


ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=epm04, aes(x=reorder(Player, -`MVP Finish`), weight=OffEPM),fill="darkgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=nash04, aes(x=reorder(Player, -`MVP Finish`), weight=OffEPM),fill="#5f259f") +
  geom_bar(data=shaq, aes(x=reorder(Player, -`MVP Finish`), weight=OffEPM),fill="#98002E")+
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Estimated Points Added", 
    title="Steve Nash Had the Biggest Effect on the Best Offense", 
    subtitle="Nash led the Suns to the best team in the league through his own offensive production.", 
    caption="Source: DunksandThrees | Nolan Rachiele"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









Comparing the players in the top ten of MVP finishes in 2005 and 2006, Nash generated points through scoring and passing the ball. Ben Taylor of Thinking Basketball created box creations that shows how many open shots a player has made for his team per 100 possessions. Nash led in 2005 by a wide margin. Steve Nash generates points at a high level and was even the most effective scorer by True Shooting percentage.


Code
four <- modern |> 
  filter(Season==2005)
five <- modern |> 
  filter(Season == 2006) |> 
  filter(!(Player == "Amar'e Stoudemire"))
sn <- modern|> 
  filter(Player == "Steve Nash")
top3 <- modern |> 
  filter(
   (Player %in% c("Steve Nash", "Shaquille O'Neal", "Dirk Nowitzki") & Season == "2005") |
    (Player %in% c("Steve Nash", "LeBron James", "Dirk Nowitzki") & Season == "2006")
  )

ggplot() + geom_point(data=four, aes(x=PPG, y=APG, size = `TS%`), alpha =.3) +
scale_size(range = c(.05, 10), name="True Shooting Percentage") +
geom_point(data=five, aes(x=PPG, y=APG, size = `TS%`), alpha =.3) +
geom_point(data=top3, aes(x=PPG, y=APG, size = `TS%`), color="#bf9a33") +
  geom_point(data=sn, aes(x=PPG, y=APG, size = `TS%`), color="#E56020") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=top3, 
    aes(x=PPG, y=APG, label=Player)
  ) +
   labs(
    x="Points Per Game", 
    y="Assists Per Game", 
    title="Steve Nash Tops the NBA in Generated Points by a Wide Margin", 
    subtitle="The Sun's point guard leads the NBA in assists and is the most productive scorer in the league.\nNash showcases his offensive prowess by being a pass first guard. ", 
    caption="Source: Basketball Reference | Nolan Rachiele"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









MVP is an award based on precedent, and Steve Nash did everything to meet the criteria. The Suns were the top team in the league with a record of 62-20. The MVP is also given to the players whose impact on the offensive end was elite compared to their peers.


Code
mvp <- rank |>
  filter(
    (player_name == "Steve Nash" & season %in% c(2005, 2006)) |
    (player_name == "Dirk Nowitzki" & season == 2007) |
    (player_name == "Kobe Bryant" & season == 2008) |
    (player_name == "LeBron James" & season %in% c(2009, 2010, 2012, 2013)) |
    (player_name == "Derrick Rose" & season == 2011) |
    (player_name == "Kevin Durant" & season == 2014)
  ) |>
  select(player_name, season, raptor_rank) |>
  arrange(desc(season))

season4 <- raptor |> 
  filter(season== 2004)


mvp |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    player_name = "Player",
    season = "Season",
    raptor_rank = "Offensive Rank"
  ) |> 
    tab_header(
    title = "Offensive Production and the Correlation to MVP",
    subtitle = "Steve Nash's two MVPs backed by top 5 finishes in RAPTOR's offensive rating."
  )  |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|> tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )) |> 
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Nolan Rachiele  |  **Source:** 538's RAPTOR Database")
  ) |> 
    opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |> 
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#5f259f"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = player_name == "Steve Nash")
  )

Steve Nash proved his MVP through his team’s performance and his offensive output. He was the Most Valuable Player in the league that year.
